variant.question: Why is it important to have accurate information about the airplane mass and CG position during flight?

options.text: It allows to select a real, optimum cruising level.
They are necessary for calculating take off and landing performance.
They are not important in commercial aviation as all data is provided.
It allows airlines to calculate the most efficient navigational route and costs.

variant.question: If the aircraft was loaded with the Centre of Gravity in front of the forward CG limit, counteracting the nose-pitching-down moment will lead to..
If the aircraft was loaded with the Centre of Gravity in front of the forward CG limit, counteracting the nose-pitching-down moment will lead to...

Given the data below calculate the C of G at TOM as a percentage of the mean aerodynamic chord:
Basic Empty Mass 1095 kg
C of G at BEM 1.98 m (25 % MAC)
Pilot and front seat occupant 80 kg each
Front seat arm 2.5 m
Rear seat arm 3.2 m
Fuel load 139 litres (SG 0.72)
Fuel arm 1.9 m
MAC 2 m
Assume a centre of gravity which is located in front of (outside) the forward limit. Due to this, the moment arm of the horizontal surfaces is:

options.text: longer than it usual is and the fuel consumption of the airplane increases.
shorter than it usual is and the drag of the airplane decreases.
longer than it usual is and the fuel consumption of the airplane decreases.
shorter than it usual is and the range of the airplane increases.

variant.question:
<u>Given:</u>
Aircraft weight: 122 600 N
CG location: 30.5% MAC
<u>Information from the flight manual:</u>
DOI = [(CG - 25) × W × 0.029] + 100
DOI = dry operating index [1]
CG = centre of gravity [% MAC]
W = aircraft weight [kN]
DOI correction for deviation from standard crew is 0.92 for +/-100 kg
